ticket.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them
ticket.original-body:
The attached patch enhances with_scope, etc. by enabling the merging of :joins specified either in the new style or old style sql fragments.
1. Where both are new style they are merged in the same manner as :include.
2. Where both are strings they are concatenated together.
3. Where one is a new style and the other is a string then the new style :joins is converted to an sql fragment and then concatenated with the other sql fragment.
4. construct_finder_sql adds the DISTINCT sql keyword to limit the number of rows returned as joins generally multiply the number of rows returned - this is an enhancement to the change in ticket #46.
5. Tests have been added and all tests pass
6. Documentation has been updated to reflect that :joins as well as :include and :conditions are merged.

1. Where both are new style they are merged in the same manner as :include.
2. Where both are strings they are concatenated together.
3. Where one is a new style and the other is a string then the new style :joins is converted to an sql fragment and then concatenated with the other sql fragment.
4. construct_finder_sql adds the DISTINCT sql keyword to limit the number of rows returned as joins generally multiply the number of rows returned - this is an enhancement to the change in ticket #46.
5. Tests have been added and all tests pass
6. Documentation has been updated to reflect that :joins as well as :include and :conditions are merged.
ticket.original-body-html:
The attached patch enhances with_scope, etc. by enabling the merging of :joins specified either in the new style or old style sql fragments.

1. Where both are new style they are merged in the same manner as :include.

2. Where both are strings they are concatenated together.

3. Where one is a new style and the other is a string then the new style :joins is converted to an sql fragment and then concatenated with the other sql fragment.

4. construct_finder_sql adds the DISTINCT sql keyword to limit the number of rows returned as joins generally multiply the number of rows returned - this is an enhancement to the change in ticket #46.

5. Tests have been added and all tests pass

6. Documentation has been updated to reflect that :joins as well as :include and :conditions are merged.

version.body:
The attached patch enhances with_scope, etc. by enabling the merging of :joins specified either in the new style or old style sql fragments.
1. Where both are new style they are merged in the same manner as :include.
2. Where both are strings they are concatenated together.
3. Where one is a new style and the other is a string then the new style :joins is converted to an sql fragment and then concatenated with the other sql fragment.
4. construct_finder_sql adds the DISTINCT sql keyword to limit the number of rows returned as joins generally multiply the number of rows returned - this is an enhancement to the change in ticket #46.
5. Tests have been added and all tests pass

version.body-html:
The attached patch enhances with_scope, etc. by enabling the merging of :joins specified either in the new style or old style sql fragments.

1. Where both are new style they are merged in the same manner as :include.

2. Where both are strings they are concatenated together.

3. Where one is a new style and the other is a string then the new style :joins is converted to an sql fragment and then concatenated with the other sql fragment.

4. construct_finder_sql adds the DISTINCT sql keyword to limit the number of rows returned as joins generally multiply the number of rows returned - this is an enhancement to the change in ticket #46.

5. Tests have been added and all tests pass

6. Documentation has been updated to reflect that :joins as well as :include and :conditions are merged.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: Hey Andrew, nice patch. Could you explain adding DISTINCT to the finder sql?
version.body-html: Hey Andrew, nice patch. Could you explain adding DISTINCT to the finder sql?
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body:
The DISTINCT is for when you're joining a has_many or habtm association - e.g. a post joined with comments:
Post.find(:all, :joins => :comments, :conditions => 'comments.approved = 1')
Ticket #46 scopes the select to the posts table (i.e. 'posts.*') but if a post has more than one comment approved you'll get back duplicate post instances. Adding 'DISTINCT posts.*' eliminates these duplicate records.
There may by some circumstances where you don't want the DISTINCT in which case you can override it with :select, but the majority of cases would need it so that's why I've added it by default.
version.body-html:
The DISTINCT is for when you're joining a has_many or habtm association - e.g. a post joined with comments:

Post.find(:all, :joins => :comments, :conditions => 'comments.approved = 1')

Ticket #46 scopes the select to the posts table (i.e. 'posts.*') but if a post has more than one comment approved you'll get back duplicate post instances. Adding 'DISTINCT posts.*' eliminates these duplicate records.

There may by some circumstances where you don't want the DISTINCT in which case you can override it with :select, but the majority of cases would need it so that's why I've added it by default.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body:
I agree with Andrew that DISTINCT would make sense in a lot of cases. However, using DISTINCT can easily become a performance problem if the query has LIMIT, ORDER BY etc. Apart from that, it'll also change the existing behavior, which can *possibly* break some stuff. So I'm not sure if it'll be a sensible default or not.
How about adding :distinct option to find ?
Interested in hearing more thoughts on this.
version.body-html:
I agree with Andrew that DISTINCT would make sense in a lot of cases. However, using DISTINCT can easily become a performance problem if the query has LIMIT, ORDER BY etc. Apart from that, it'll also change the existing behavior, which can possibly break some stuff. So I'm not sure if it'll be a sensible default or not.

How about adding :distinct option to find ?

Interested in hearing more thoughts on this.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: We could do a :distinct option and then set it true by default if we detect a has_many or habtm join being specified. This would only be when using the new style join syntax limiting any backward compatibility problems.
version.body-html: We could do a :distinct option and then set it true by default if we detect a has_many or habtm join being specified. This would only be when using the new style join syntax limiting any backward compatibility problems.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: I'm not convinced about setting it to default.
version.body-html: I'm not convinced about setting it to default.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body:
If we don't set it as the default when the destination join has more than one matching row then we'll get duplicate instances of the parent. I can't think of a use case where this would correct or useful.
However looking at count it sets :distinct => true for :include and leaves it out when using :joins, so I guess the precedent is to make the developer specify it.
version.body-html:
If we don't set it as the default when the destination join has more than one matching row then we'll get duplicate instances of the parent. I can't think of a use case where this would correct or useful.

However looking at count it sets :distinct => true for :include and leaves it out when using :joins, so I guess the precedent is to make the developer specify it.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body:
I've modified the patch to only merge :joins and not bother about making the select statement distinct. I'll create a separate ticket and patch for adding a distinct option to find.
One question regarding the distinct option for find - which of the following would be better:
Post.find :all, :distinct => true, :joins => :comments
or
Post.find :distinct, :joins => :comments
version.body-html:
I've modified the patch to only merge :joins and not bother about making the select statement distinct. I'll create a separate ticket and patch for adding a distinct option to find.

One question regarding the distinct option for find - which of the following would be better:

Post.find :all, :distinct => true, :joins => :comments

or

Post.find :distinct, :joins => :comments
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body:
"Post.find :all, :distinct => true, :joins => :comments"
We can always do "Post.all, :distinct => true, :joins => :comments" once that's done.
version.body-html:
"Post.find :all, :distinct => true, :joins => :comments"

We can always do "Post.all, :distinct => true, :joins => :comments" once that's done.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: The patch looks good. Could you rebase against master?
version.body-html: The patch looks good. Could you rebase against master?
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: Updated patch rebased against master
version.body-html: Updated patch rebased against master
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body:
(from [db22c89543f45d7f27847003af949afa21cb6fa1]) Merge scoped :joins together instead of overwriting them. May expose scoping bugs in your code!
[#501 state:resolved]
Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper <jeremy@bitsweat.net> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/db22c89543f45d7f27847003af949afa21cb6fa1
version.body-html:
(from [db22c89543f45d7f27847003af949afa21cb6fa1]) Merge scoped :joins together instead of overwriting them. May expose scoping bugs in your code!

[#501 state:resolved]

Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper jeremy@bitsweat.net http://github.com/rails/rails/co...
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body:
**Wait!**
Is there a reason merge_joins isn't used inside of with_scope to merge joins there too?
Without it in that location, it's not possible to chain multiple named_scopes that have joins.
version.body-html:
Wait!

Is there a reason merge_joins isn't used inside of with_scope to merge joins there too?

Without it in that location, it's not possible to chain multiple named_scopes that have joins.
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: It is used in with_scope - chaining multiple named scopes works fine for me. Do you have an example that doesn't work?
version.body-html: It is used in with_scope - chaining multiple named scopes works fine for me. Do you have an example that doesn't work?
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: What happened to the patch for DISTINCT to work?
version.body-html: What happened to the patch for DISTINCT to work?
version.title: Merge :joins instead of clobbering them

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
